metadata.title: Nano-Engineered Multiblock Copolymer Nanoparticles via Reversible Addition–Fragmentation Chain Transfer Emulsion Polymerization

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text:
Large-scale phase separation of chemically incompatible polymers in materials science often negatively impacts the final properties of the material. However, when such polymers are properly combined into discrete nano-sized domains as covalently linked entities, materials with improved properties can be accessed.1 Block copolymers composed of polymer segments that are able to phase-separate can undergo selfassembly into complex nanostructured materials (microphase separation) exhibiting improved properties, which can be exploited in various fields such as nanomedicine,2 advanced plastics,3 and microelectronics.4,5 The majority of these advanced materials are, to date, obtained from the most simple case of AB diblock copolymers using different chemical compositions of each block. Therefore, by increasing the number of blocks beyond two, resulting in so called multiblock copolymers, a myriad of nano-engineered materials can
potentially be prepared.4 Hence, complex materials exhibiting fascinating morphologies and properties become within synthetic reach. However, one of the criteria for microphase separation to occur is that the molecular weights of the individual blocks are sufficiently high. Microphase separation occurs if the quantity χN is sufficiently high, where χ is the Flory−Huggins segmental interaction parameter and N is the degree of polymerization.6
Since the pioneering work on the synthesis of high-order multiblock copolymers via reversible deactivation radical polymerization (RDRP) in 2011,7 various reports on the preparation of multiblock copolymers have demonstrated how RDRP can be a powerful tool to control the chemical

composition and monomer sequence distribution of macromolecules.7−17 These synthetic approaches allow one to create a range of complex polymer architectures exhibiting properties hitherto inaccessibleeffectively a new generation of synthetic polymers. However, an effective method to synthesize highorder multiblock copolymers via RDRP must fulfill several requirements: (i) must be applicable to a wide range of monomers, (ii) must have a high degree of livingness (chain end fidelity) of the chains, and (iii) the method should be straightforward with no intermediate purification steps. Among these points, livingness must be highlightedit was the relatively recent realization that high livingness can be obtained at near full monomer conversion by careful optimization/ selection of the RDRP system/conditions7,9 that led to a revolution in high-order multiblock copolymer synthesis. The livingness refers to the number fraction of living chains, that is, chains possessing an ω-end group that can be reactivated, thus allowing further chain extension. Recently, Gody et al.9,10 reported a one-pot strategy to synthesize an acrylamide-based multiblock copolymer comprising up to 20 blocks via sequential reversible addition−fragmentation chain transfer
(RAFT) polymerization. The degree of livingness was demonstrated to be a key parameter for the synthesis of well-defined multiblock copolymers. In RAFT polymerization,18−20 optimization in regard to livingness entails use of conditions such that a high propagating rate is achieved using as low an initiation rate as possible. This is a consequence of the fact that the number of dead chains in RAFT polymerization is dictated by the number of radicals generated by the radical initiator, given that all radicals eventually terminate. This also explains why it is easier to synthesize multiblock copolymers of low molecular weightsthe lower the target molecular weight, the higher the livingness (at a fixed initiator concentration), since the number of living chains is higher, and the number of dead chains remains the same under ideal conditions for a given initiator concentration and polymerization time. It follows that this strategy can only be efficiently applied to monomers with high propagation rate coefficients such as acrylate and acrylamide derivatives (otherwise sufficiently high conversion cannot be reached). Alternatively, heterogeneous systems such as emulsion polymerization can be applied to multiblock copolymer

synthesis. In this case, the segregation effect, that is, how chemical reactions are influenced by physical confinement of reactants to small spaces such as latex particles (compartmentalization), is exploited to reduce the termination rate and thus increase the polymerization rate.21−28 Following the reasoning above, these conditions can be exploited in RAFT polymerization for the synthesis of polymer chains exhibiting a high degree of livingness. On the basis of this concept, Engelis et al.8 reported a successful strategy for the synthesis of methacrylatebased multiblock copolymers (up to 21 blocks) via “sulfur-free RAFT” emulsion polymerization using methacrylate-type macromonomers. Excellent control was obtained resulting in well-defined multiblock copolymers; however, the molecular weight was limited to 50,000 g·mol−1, and the technique was strictly employed to methacrylates. Furthermore, this method relies on a semicontinuous process, whereby a low instantaneous monomer concentration is maintained via use of a continuous monomer feed. The achievement by Engelis et al.8 builds on earlier works by Moad and co-workers, demonstrating that methacrylate-based copolymers (up to six blocks) can be prepared by “sulfur-free RAFT” conducted as emulsion polymerization.29−32
Recently, Yan et al.33 reported a successful strategy based on macromolecular RAFT agent (macroRAFT)-assisted emulsion polymerization to synthesize high MW polystyrene. Poly(acrylic acid)-b-polystyrene (PAA20-b-PS5-TTC) was first prepared in a separate step and used as both the chain transfer agent (CTA) and colloidal stabilizer, resulting in a polymer exhibiting high MW and relatively low dispersity (Mn = 544,000 g·mol−1; Đ = 1.26). Importantly, a low concentration of a conventional initiator was used ([RAFT]/[Initiator] = 40), leading to the formation of polymer chains exhibiting a high degree of livingness. In a similar strategy, Truong et al.34 reported the preparation of ultrahigh MW PS (Mn > 1,000,000 g·mol−1; Đ = 1.39) using a macroRAFT based on poly(ethylene glycol) methyl ether acrylate (PEGA, Mn ∼ 480 g· mol−1) and N-hydroxyethyl acrylamide (HEAA). In the present work, we have exploited the use of macroRAFT-assisted emulsion polymerization to synthesize high-order multiblock copolymer based on the strategy schematically illustrated in Figure 1A. A PAA24-b-PS8-TTC macroRAFT agent is synthesized and then used as both the CTA and stabilizer in the emulsion polymerization of styrene. Sequential seeded emulsion polymerizations are subsequently carried out using various monomers (acrylates, methacrylates, and styrene), thus generating high-order multiblock copolymers. A soft/hard thermoplastic elastomer material is presented with the synthesis of poly(butyl acrylate) (PBA)PS pentablock copolymers. In addition, the ability to control the chemical composition on the molecular scale to generate nano-engineered polymer particles is demonstrated through the synthesis of pentablock copolymers composed of poly(butyl methacrylate) (PBMA) and PS blocks. These polymers are able to undergo phase separation within the discrete nanoparticles, thus generating well-defined multilayered morphological structures.

sections.heading: 2. RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
sections.text:
Initially, we focus on the synthesis of polystyrene nonablock homopolymers (nine chain extensions) as a model system (Figure 1B). Styrene is considered a low kp monomer, and because of its slow polymerization, a higher initiator concentration is required, which in turn leads to lower
livingnessthis is a significant issue in regard to multiblock copolymer synthesis. Hence, by using a heterogeneous system, that is, emulsion polymerization, the segregation effect can be exploited to increase the polymerization rate by reducing the bimolecular termination rate.
2.1. Synthesis of Nonablock Multiblock Homopolymers as a Model System. A PAA24-b-PS8-TTC amphiphilic macroRAFT was synthesized in two-step solution polymerization in dioxane (see detailed experimental conditions in Table SI1 and 1H NMR and SEC data in the Supporting Information). The block lengths were carefully selected based on a previous work35 to (i) keep the macroRAFT sufficiently hydrophilic to be water-soluble, (ii) obtain good colloidal stability of the formed particles, and (iii) provide rapid nucleation to avoid a long induction period. The pH of the initial macroRAFT solution is a crucial parameter when the macroRAFT containing carboxylic acid functionality is used.36,37 A low pH value will lead to protonation of carboxylic groups from acrylic acid units, disfavoring colloidal stability. At high pH, poor control of the polymerization is typically observed as manifested in broad MWDs, proposed to be caused by hydrolysis of trithiocarbonate RAFT end groups38,39 and/or by the high pH affecting the mechanism of particle nucleation.36,37 Wang et al.37 reported a successful strategy to address this issue. Acidic conditions were applied only at the beginning of the polymerization, favoring RAFT control, and an amount of NaOH was added after the nucleation step to improve the colloidal stability. We applied a similar strategy in the present work, adding a sufficient amount of NaOH to deprotonate 20 units of acrylic acid per chain (approximately 80% of the number of acrylic acid units in each macroRAFT) after 150 min of polymerization. Eight sequential seeded emulsion polymerizations of styrene were subsequently conducted with 3 h intervals, resulting in PS nonablock homopolymers. Initiator was only added after every third polymerization cycle (first, fourth, and seventh cycle; Table SI2) to maximize the livingness. High conversion determined by 1H NMR was observed for each block (>92%; Figure SI3). Because monomer is added before each polymerization step, it is of interest whether the existing polymer particles are capable of swelling with monomer to the extent that a free monomer phase (monomer droplets) does not exist. The monomer concentration in the particles before polymerization based on the assumption that there are no monomer droplets (i.e., all monomer absorbed by polymer particles) was calculated for each polymerization cycle (Table SI3). The results indicate that the presence of monomer droplets is expected only for the first cycle (nucleation step) and the second cycle of polymerization ([S]particle = 8.0 M). After the third cycle, the styrene concentration gradually decreases from 4.3 down to 1.8 M (from third to ninth cycle)these values are lower than the reported saturated concentration of styrene in PS particles at 50 °C ([S]sat‑particle = 5.5 M for unswollen particles with a diameter of 94 nm).40,41 The presence of monomer droplets can be an important aspect of RAFT emulsion polymerization because it leads to a high ratio of [RAFT]/[Mon] (compared to the corresponding homogeneous system where no monomer is segregated from the locus of polymerization), that is, fewer monomer units are added per activation/ deactivation cycle, which favors low dispersity of the MWDs. The SEC traces shifted toward a higher MW after each cycle of polymerization (Figure 2), indicating the successful formation of the multiblock copolymer. However, after the sixth cycle of

It is important to highlight that a PS nonablock homopolymer would be extremely challenging, if not impossible, to prepare using RAFT solution polymerizationthe intrinsically low polymerization rate of this low kp monomer would require a significantly higher initiation rate to reach full conversion, thus leading to substantially reduced degrees of livingness. Low-dispersity particles were obtained after the first cycle of polymerization as can be observed in the TEM micrographs (Figure 4A). Such low-dispersity size distributions were observed after each cycle of polymerization, resulting in the final particles displayed in Figure 4B (see additional TEM images and their respective histograms in Figure SI4). Statistical analysis was performed based on the particle size measured from the TEM images, resulting in the histograms
shown in Figure 4C. A monomodal size distribution was observed for each block, confirming the absence of secondary nucleation. As expected, the number-average particle diameter increases with the degree of polymerization (DP) (Figure 5A), while the dispersity remains low (Dw/Dn ≈ 1.1). PBA-PS Pentablock Multiblock Copolymer: Thermoplastic Elastomer. The synthesis of block copolymers composed of butyl acrylate (BA) and styrene by RAFT polymerization has been attracting great interest over the past two decades39,43−47 because of the promising properties of the potentially formed materials. However, the synthesis of such block copolymers has been demonstrated to be a significant challenge, and most of the reported strategies result in broad MWDs (Đ > 2),39,43,44,47 which are associated with chain transfer reactions inducing polymer branching. In the present system, when pure BA monomer was used in the second polymerization cycle, unsatisfactory results were obtained in terms of low conversion (Table SI4 and Figure SI5). Attempts were made to overcome this problem by increasing the reaction time (Table SI5 and Figure SI6) or increasing the initiator concentration while also decreasing the degree of deprotonation of the PAA segment (Table SI6 and Figure SI7);48 however, only low conversion was still observed. It was subsequently decided to add 10 wt % of styrene (Table SI7), a strategy previously reported by Chaduc et al.,39 which resulted in full conversion (X = 99% for all blocks except for the first block, X = 97%; Figure SI8) after 18 h polymerization (instead of 3 h as described above) and monomodal particle size distribution (Figure SI9). It has been proposed39 that the presence of styrene generates a higher concentration of styrene-terminated macroradicals compared to BA-terminated radicals, thus drastically reducing the chain transfer to polymer39 and/or reducing the rate of addition of PBA· macroradicals to RAFT moieties.49 SEC traces (Figure 8) confirm the successful synthesis of the pentablock copolymer (Figure 1C) with the main peak shifting toward higher MWs. A triblock copolymer with Đ < 1.5 was obtained (Figure 3), indicating that excessive branching did not occur. However, after the fourth and fifth cycle of polymerization, MWD broadening was observed, which can be attributed to some inevitable loss of livingness (Table SI7). 2.3. Nano-Engineered PBMA-PS Pentablock Particles. Having established that the particle growth proceeds exclusively via individual chain growth (negligible coagulation and secondary nucleation) and that the chains have sufficient length to reach from the particle surface to the particle center, we further develop the concept of particle nano-engineering, targeting an AB pentablock copolymer as illustrated in Figure 1D. PBMA and PS, polymers that are chemically incompatible and thus able to undergo phase separation,50 were selected (the PBA-PS system above is also able to undergo phase separation, but due to the low Tg of the PBA segments, TEM
investigations would be challenging). On the basis of this concept and the calculations presented above, it is expected that multilayered particles, possessing what is known as “onion”-like multilayered morphology will form as illustrated in Figure 10. As a first step, an experiment using BMA (Table SI8) for the second block was carried out, resulting in low conversion of only approximately 5% (NMR spectra in Figure SI10). To overcome this problem, a small amount of styrene (10 wt %, Table SI9) was added as discussed above,51 and the time for each polymerization cycle involving BMA was increased to 18 h, resulting in full conversion after each cycle of polymerization (99% except for the first block, where X = 96%; Figure SI11) and low-dispersity particles (Figure SI12). In addition, SEC traces show the shift of the main peak toward higher MWs, consistent with a linear increase in MW after each polymerization cycle (Figures 3 and 9), confirming the successful preparation of a pentablock copolymer.

F
We now turn our attention to the particle morphology. To this end, a pentablock copolymer (run 8, Table SI10) with a higher PS content was synthesized to obtain solid particles that do not undergo film formation (the PBMA-PS pentablock latex, run 7, undergoes film formation upon evaporation of water at room temperature due to the low Tg (20 °C) of the PBMA segment). The scheme in Figure 10 illustrates each step of particle growth, depicting the expected (“ideal”) morphology after each cycle of polymerization. The expected morphology for second block is clearly evident (additional TEM images are shown in Figure SI13); however, after the third cycle of polymerization, the morphologies cannot be clearly observed using normal TEM, except for the fifth block in which the TEM image provides evidence of the expected multilayer morphology (the rougher surface of the particles observed for the BMA-rich systems, second, fourth, and fifth blocks, is ascribed to drying artifacts due to the low Tg). The TEM observation of ultrathin cross sections of particles obtained via embedding in an epoxy resin followed by slicing was subsequently conducted to expose the internal morphology. Figure 11 reveals that four-layered particles have indeed formed (Figure 11 and Figure SI14), with the lighter layer representing PBMA segments and the darker ones representing the PS segments (due to higher electronic density of PS). This multilayer morphology could be anticipated based on microphase separation of these multiblock copolymers and also considering that each new block grows from within the particle center (where, ideally, the RAFT end groups are located, considering chains stretching from the particle surface to particle core). It is important to point out that a pentablock copolymer was synthesized, and one may thus anticipate five layers as opposed to only four (Figure 11 and Figure SI14). This discrepancy can be explained by considering the short length of the last PS block (only 50 units of styrene), which is insufficient to cause phase separation from the PBMA-rich phase. Overall, this multilayered morphology demonstrated is an impressive result that shows how both the number and the composition of each layer of the nano-engineered particles can be readily controlled via a judicious choice of monomers in each step of the sequential RAFT emulsion polymerization. Although particles of similar onion-layered structures have been reported using other approaches,52−62 the present work represents (to the best of our knowledge) the first time that
the number of layers of nano-engineered particles can be accurately controlled. Furthermore, on the basis of the previous strategies reported,52−62 a multilayered particle with versatile control of the composition of each layer would not be readily accessibleor close to impossible to achieveas selfassembly approaches based on diblock copolymers (i.e., only two monomer types) were employed. Our strategy can, in principle, be extended to multiple monomer types. This result also confirms our calculations presented above for the polystyrene model system showing that one single multiblock chain can be extended from the surface to the center of the particle.

sections.heading: 3. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text:
We have developed an approach for the successful synthesis of multiblock copolymers based on sequential emulsion polymerization using the three most commonly employed monomer families in emulsion polymerization systems: methacrylates, acrylates, and styrene. By exploiting the segregation effect (compartmentalization), a high molar mass polymer (up to 140,000 g·mol−1) was obtained in a relatively short time period for each cycle of polymerization (3 h). In addition, the morphology of the resulting polymer particles could be nanoengineered by successful control of the polymer composition, leading to the formation of multilayered particles, demonstrating how precise control of the composition can be a powerful tool for development of a new class of nano-engineered particles. This concept was demonstrated with a PBMA-PS pentablock copolymer. This strategy developed can be exploited for the synthesis of particles with several layers in which each layer is composed of a different polymer, thus leading to the formation of multilayered particles with tailored composition of each layer, unlike the previous methods for the synthesis of multilayered particles that are restricted to two monomer types (one single diblock copolymer). It is also important to point out that this strategy is considered as a “green” method, given that it employs water as the solvent. Finally, the method fulfills all the main requirements for scale up to an industrial process such as no intermediated purification steps, relative high solid content in a batch process, good colloidal stability with no flocculation/ coagulation, near full conversion, and use of low concentration of the RAFT agent (high molecular weight polymer targeted).

metadata.abstractText: Block copolymers composed of polymer segments of sufficiently high molecular weight such that microphase separation and self-assembly into complex nanostructured materials can occur provide a pathway to a myriad of nano-engineered materials with applications ranging from nanomedicine to materials science and microelectronics. In the present work, we have developed a methodology based on reversible addition−fragmentation chain transfer polymerization that allows the synthesis of multiblock copolymers based on sequential aqueous emulsion polymerization using the three most common industrially employed monomer families in emulsion polymerization systems: methacrylates, acrylates, and styrene. By exploiting the segregation effect (compartmentalization) resulting from polymerization within polymeric nanoparticles, a high molecular weight multiblock copolymer (up to 140,000 g·mol−1) is obtained in a relative short time period of 3 h for each cycle of polymerization. The concept of nano-engineering of polymer nanoparticle morphology is demonstrated by exploiting the ability to covalently link numerous polymer blocks that are chemically incompatible, resulting in microphase separation and the formation of a well-defined multilayered structure within the nanoparticles. The method developed is environmentally friendly (use of water as solvent) and fulfills all requirements for scale up to an industrial process using existing industrial equipment such as no intermediate purification steps, relatively high solid content, good colloidal stability with no flocculation/coagulation, and near full monomer conversion.
